column1: Walter Dane was in a hurry to go off to play at ball with some of his schoolfellows; and so he did not give much thought to the lesson which he had to learn.It was a lesson in grammar. Walter's mother took the book
column3: "I fear my little boy finds it hard to put his thoughts on his lesson today.""Try me
column5: said Walter. I will do my best.""Then
column6: I will put you a question which is not in the book
column7: said mamma. Which is the heavier
column9: or a pound of lead?""A pound of lead
column10: to be sure!" cried Walter confidently."There! you spoke then without thinking
column11: said Mrs. Dane. A little thought would have made it clear to you that a pound is a pound
column12: and that a pound of feathers must weigh just as much as a pound of lead."
